texts.definition: The event which makes a player no long able to participate in the gameplay of a game instance.
markups: <style="Definition">The event which makes a player no long able to participate in the gameplay of a game instance.</style>

Most games are design to end at some point, and some are designed to make some players stop playing before all other do. A <style="CurrentLink">Game Over</style> event is when a player is locked out from gameplay due to some rule in the game.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asteroids">Asteroids</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Donkey%20Kong">Donkey Kong</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Out%20Run">Out Run</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pong">Pong</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pac-Man">Pac-Man</link></style> are all games where players experience <style="CurrentLink">Game Over</style> when they run out of lives. However, in original <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Arcade%20Games">Arcade</link></style> version it was possible to pay for more lives. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Gauntlet">Gauntlet</link></style> is a latter example.

Getting killed in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Counter-Strike%20series">Counter-Strike series</link></style> or losing one's last card in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Coup">Coup</link></style> results in players being thrown out of the game. However, since each game round is so short and one typically play many rounds back-to-back, the effects of <style="CurrentLink">Game Over</style> are not too severe.

Designing <style="CurrentLink">Game Over</style> events in a game consists of choosing what causes them. A typical cause is simple that it is a <style="Link"><link="game-termination-penalties">Game Termination Penalty</link></style> or the logical conclusion of <style="Link"><link="death-consequences">Death Consequences</link></style> when a players have lost all <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style> or suffers from a <style="Link"><link="permadeath">Permadeath</link></style> event. However, <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style> (and <style="Link"><link="team-elimination">Team Elimination</link></style>) or <style="Link"><link="player-kicking">Player Kicking</link></style> can also function as can <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> that create <style="Link"><link="time-limited-game-instances">Time Limited Game Instances</link></style>. Of course, winning a game also causes a <style="CurrentLink">Game Over</style> but the pattern can also be applied to <style="Link"><link="unwinnable-games">Unwinnable Games</link></style> since <style="CurrentLink">Game Over</style> events can be penalties.

<style="Link"><link="end-state-scoring">End State Scoring</link></style> is an option to add some <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> after gameplay has ended and can be used to support <style="Link"><link="winner-gameplay-ends">Winner determined after Gameplay Ends</link></style>. Related to this, players are encouraged to create <style="CurrentLink">Game Over</style> events for everyone when <style="Link"><link="speedending">Speedending</link></style> is perceived as a good strategy.

Another, which adds a consequence and possible goal to want to reach a <style="CurrentLink">Game Over</style> event, is to use <style="Link"><link="winning-ending-gameplay">Winning by Ending Gameplay</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="pay-play">Pay to Play</link></style> is an option to let players begin playing again if they are willing to play.

While <style="Link"><link="fake-game-overs">Fake Game Overs</link></style> quite clearly aren't <style="CurrentLink">Game Over</style> events, they can be used to trick players into believing they're experience such for some time.

<style="CurrentLink">Game Over</style> causes players to not be able to play. In practice this becomes <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style> if another game instance will start soon, as is the structure of quick games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Coup">Coup</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Resistance">The Resistance</link></style> but otherwise can force the former players to start doing something else. Unless <style="CurrentLink">Game Over</style> occurs to all players at the same time in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, it can create <style="Link"><link="unsynchronized-game-sessions">Unsynchronized Game Sessions</link></style>.

The introduction of <style="CurrentLink">Game Over</style> events being possible is likely to create <style="Link"><link="extermination">Extermination</link></style> phases. Likewise, identifiable points in gameplay time when the risk of <style="CurrentLink">Game Over</style> events increase markedly can also signify the beginning of <style="Link"><link="extermination">Extermination</link></style> phases.
